Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my laptop—ten minutes until my volunteer shift started. My mentor’s message blinked on the screen: “Let me know if you have any questions.” I did have a question, a small one about terminology in the project brief. It wasn’t urgent, but I remembered how she emphasized the importance of open communication. “Don’t hesitate to reach out, even for minor things,” she’d said. I hesitated, fingers hovering over the keyboard. If I messaged her now, she might reply immediately, expecting a quick back-and-forth. But I was the only volunteer scheduled to unlock the community center, and people would already be waiting outside. If I left late, I’d keep everyone waiting in the cold. If I didn’t message my mentor, I’d be ignoring her advice and maybe seem disengaged. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations—responsible mentee, reliable volunteer—each pulling me in a different direction, both demanding my presence at the same moment.
